feed.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System

entry.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: In a recent discussion, Antoine Riard addressed the concern of front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace. Front-running refers to entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security. Antoine described a scenario involving Mary the Maker, Terry the Taker, and Bob the bulletin board operator. Mary publishes a limit order to buy a derivative, and Bob, as the bulletin board operator, has the option to execute against Mary's order. If Bob chooses not to execute, he relays the order to Terry and other subscribers to his market. Terry then has the option to execute a trade against Mary's limit order, and if he decides not to, Mary's order sits on the bulletin board.Antoine argues that this model is not a major concern, as Bob can collect outsized profits from his trusted position as the bulletin board operator. Eventually, Terry may move to other markets because Bob is only relaying what he perceives to be unprofitable orders. From Mary's perspective, she is happy because her order got executed at the price she specified. However, Terry is the one who loses in this model, which ends up looking more like a brokerage than an exchange market structure. Antoine suggests that Terry should open his own brokerage (bulletin board) and compete on quoting prices with Bob.Additionally, Antoine discusses the idea of comparing Bob and Terry on metrics like execution quality, which can draw more market activity since they would be providing better prices. He also mentions the concept of front-running being a "champagne" issue to have because it indicates active participants and liquidity in the market. Antoine believes that finding what products people are interested in trading and providing them with a good user experience is more important, as everything else will fall in line after that.Antoine also explores different security paradigms to mitigate front-running risks in a peer-to-peer marketplace. One approach is to duplicate the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities and monitor latency. Latency anomalies can be detected by a watchtower-like infrastructure, and if repeated anomalies occur, a maker can disqualify the misbehaving board. Another paradigm involves running the bulletin boards as a federation using Honey Badger BFT, where incoming offers become consensus items that must be announced to all federation members before publication.In conclusion, Antoine emphasizes that the CivKit framework for a peer-to-peer marketplace provides flexibility in adapting front-running resistance parameters based on the types of trades and market participants involved. The configuration of these parameters will depend on real-world deployments and may involve trade-offs between security and usability.The authors of the paper express their gratitude to the peer reviewers for their input on the architecture of the system. They announce their plans to release code and modules gradually, leveraging the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries. These releases will adhere to the established open-source and decentralized standards of Bitcoin Core. The authors also express their enthusiasm for collaborating with the community to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients in the long run. Feedback on their work is encouraged and welcomed. The message is signed by Nick, Ray, and Antoine. The context includes several links that provide additional information. The first link [0] leads to a mailing list post where the paper is discussed. The second link [1] directs to the official documentation of the DID Core standard. The third link [2] leads to the Privacypass website, which provides further information about the project. Lastly, the fourth link [4] leads to the website of the Lightning Dev Kit.Overall, the authors are actively engaging with the community and embracing collaboration to advance the development and standardization of libraries in the Bitcoin ecosystem.
